text: It only takes a tiny piece of peanut to cause a big allergic reaction in some people. An allergy by the way, is a condition that makes you feel ill after eating, touching or breathing in a particular substance.

text: Well, we'll find out if that's the right answer later on. Now let's listen to Dr Marianne Williams talking about why being too clean may not be a good thing. She is a dietician here in the UK.

speaker: INSERT
text: For roughly the first month of life the immune system is switched off in essence and everything they [babies] get exposed to in that first month in life – dogs, cats, aunts, uncles, grannies, grandpas, family, dirt – everything – that is where they build up all the bacteria that are then going to colonise their gut in the future. Now, if you're born into a very sterile environment, as is increasingly the case in the western world, everything's kept terribly clean, and one of the theories is that we just are not getting enough exposure to a variety of bacteria at that very very early stage in that first month of life.

speaker: immune systemswitched off
text: Dr Marianne Williams. The immune system is our body's defence against infection. And it's switched off – or not working – for the first month of a baby's life.

speaker: colonise
text: And through exposure to lots of things in our environment – that's family, pets, dirt and so on – young babies meet different bacteria for the first time which colonise – or live and grow in – their guts.

speaker: getexposed to  Sterile
text: Yes, but in a sterile environment babies don't get exposed to – or don't meet – a wide enough variety of bacteria. Sterile means completely clean and free of bacteria. And there's a theory that being too clean and bacteria-free – now we have soap, antibiotics and better sanitation – has lead to an increase in allergies.

speaker: Neil
text: So dirty play for babies is good – mud, pets, picking stuff up off the floor and eating it.

speaker: Alice
text: Did you use to eat food off the floor when you were little, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Used to? I still do. I enjoy food from the floor!

speaker: gluten
text: Well, Neil, what can I say? We're both lucky to be allergy-free. I have a friend who has an allergy to gluten – a protein found in wheat and some other grains – and she has to be very careful about what she eats so she doesn't get ill.

speaker: Neil
text: The supermarkets are quite helpful, though, aren't they, with products 'free from this' and 'free from that'?

speaker: proven
text: This is helpful, yes. But the food industry is now marketing their products to attract consumers who don't have a proven – or tested – allergy.

speaker: Neil
text: Why would you buy free-from foods if you don't have a food allergy?

speaker: rickets
text: Well, people have started to believe that certain foods – like gluten or dairy – are bad for us, though there isn't any medical evidence to support this. Let's hear about how rickets – a disease caused by a lack of Vitamin D in the diet – is affecting some children in the UK. This is BBC reporter Mike Williams.

speaker: Mike Williams,BBC reporter
text: Mike Williams, BBC reporter

speaker: Mike Williams,BBC reporter
text: Rickets is common in the developing world but this is London in the 21st century. These children aren't malnourished because they're too poor to eat well – it's the opposite. Their often middle-class parents are spending money to give them foods with ingredients taken out. It's as if some of us have become unnecessarily frightened of our food.

speaker: malnourished
text: Rickets usually affects malnourished childrenfrom poor countries– children who don't have enough to eat – and it makes their bones weak. But here in London some parents are buying their children expensive free-from foods – for example to avoid dairy – and are sometimes making them very ill.

speaker: Alice

speaker: nuts

speaker: Alice
text: Very good.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes. Nuts - that means crazy. Now I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question.

speaker: Alice
text: OK, then. So earlier in the show I asked: What substance is used to treat a severe allergic reaction? Is it… a) penicillin?  b) adrenalin?  Or c) aspirin?

speaker: Neil
text: I said a) penicillin.

speaker: anaphylaxis
text: And you were wrong, Neil! The correct answer is b) adrenalin. An injection of adrenalin can be used to treat anaphylaxis – or severe allergic reactions – to insect stings, foods, drugs, and other allergens. Antibiotics such as penicillin treat bacterial infections and aspirin is a painkiller you might take for a headache.
